description: TO REQUEST THE PRESIDENT TO FURNISH A COPY OF ANY INSTRUCTIONS HE MAY HAVE GIVEN TO THE MINISTER TO ENGLAND WITH RESPECT TO THE TITLE AND OCCUPATION OF OREGON, TOGETHER WITH COPY OF ANY CORRESPONDENCE BETWEEN THE TWO COUNTRIES REGARDING THIS SUBJECT.
TO POSTPONE INDEFINITELY, THE BILL S. 16, SETTLING THE TITLE TO PEA PATCH ISLAND IN THE DELAWARE RIVER.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF GEORGE H. PROFFIT AS ENVOY EXTRAORDINARY AND MINISTER PLENIPOTENTIARY TO BRAZIL, IN PLACE OF WILLIAM HUNTER, RECALLED.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF DAVID HENSHAW AS SECRETARY OF THE NAVY IN PLACE OF ABEL P. UPSHUR, RESIGNED.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF ISSAC HILL AS CHIEF OF BUREAUS OF PROVISIONS AND CLOTHING OF THE NAVY DEPARTMENT TO FILL VACANCY CAUSED BY DEATH OF CHARLES W. GOLDSBOROUGH.

TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION CONSENTING TO RATIFICATION OF THE CONVENTION FOR THE SURRENDER OF CRIMINALS BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND THE KING OF FRANCE, SIGNED AT WASHINGTON, NOV. 9, 1843, BY THE SECRETARY OF STATE AND THE MINISTER PLENIPOTENIARY AD INTERIM FROM THE FRENCH GOVERNMENT TO THE UNITED STATES.

TO AMEND, AS IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, RESOLUTION RELATING TO THE CONVENTION FOR SETTLEMENT OF CLAIMS OF THE CITIZENS AND GOVERNMENT OF THE MEXICAN REPUBLIC AGAINST THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT; AND OF THE CITIZENS AND GOVERNMENT OF THE UNITED STATES AGAINST THE MEXICAN GOVERNMENT, SIGNED IN MEXICO CITY, NOV. 20, 1843, BY PROVIDING THAT THE WORD 'MEXICO', IN ARTICLE 4, LINE 2 AND IN ARTICLE 7, LINE 22 SHALL STAND, (AS THE PLACE WHERE THE TREATY WAS CONCLUDED).

TO AMEND, AS IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, RESOLUTION RELATING TO THE CONVENTION FOR SETTLEMENT OF CLAIMS OF THE CITIZENS AND GOVERNMENT OF THE MEXICAN REPUBLIC AGAINST THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT; AND OF THE CITIZENS AND GOVERNMENT OF THE U.S. AGAINST THE MEXICAN GOVERNMENT, SIGNED IN MEXICO CITY, NOV. 20, 1843, BY INSERTING THE WORD 'WASHINGTON' IN LIEU OF THE WORD 'MEXICO' IN BOTH ARTICLE 4, LINE 2 AND ARTICLE 7, LINE 22, AS THE PLACE WHERE TREATY WAS CONCLUDED.

TO PERMIT THE GOVERNMENT TO PRINT COPIES OF A RESOLUTION FROM THE STATE OF MASS. PROPOSING TO AMEND THE CONSTITUTION SO THAT REPRESENTATION SHALL BE APPORTIONED ACCORDING TO THE RESPECTIVE NUMBER OF FREE PERSONS RESIDING IN EACH STATE.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF JAMES M. PORTER, AS SECRETARY OF WAR IN PLACE OF JOHN C. SPENCER, RESIGNED.

TO DECIDE THE QUESTION, MADE IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, JAN. 30, 1844, SHALL ARTICLE 16 STAND AS PART OF CONVENTION FOR SETTLEMENT OF CLAIMS OF THE CITIZENS AND GOVERNMENT; AND THE CITIZENS AND GOVERNMENT OF THE UNITED STATES AGAINST THE MEXICAN GOVERNMENT, SIGNED IN MEXICO CITY, NOV. 20, 1843, WHICH ARTICLE PROVIDES FOR ARBITRATION OF MUTUAL CLAIMS OF MEX. AND THE U.S., DECISION OF ARBITER TO BE FINAL AND TO BE GIVEN WITHIN ONE YEAR: THAT ALL CASES INVOLVING NATIONAL HONOR BE TREATED DIPLOMATICALLY; AND THAT NO BOUNDARY QUESTION BE SUBMITTED TO ARBITER BUT SHALL BE ARRANGED ACCORDING TO STIPULATIONS OF EXISTING TREATIES BETWEEN THE TWO COUNTRIES.

TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION AS AMENDED, CONSENTING TO RATIFICATION OF THE CONVENTION FOR SETTLEMENT OF CLAIMS OF THE CITIZENS AND GOVT OF THE MEXICAN REPUBLIC AGAINST THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT; AND OF THE CITIZENS AND GOVERNMENT OF THE U.S. AGAINST THE MEXICAN GOVERNMENT, SIGNED IN MEXICO CITY, NOV. 20, 1843.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF JOHN C. SPENCER AS ASSOCIATE JUSTICE OF THE SUPREME COURT IN PLACE OF SMITH THOMPSON, DECEASED.

TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION RATIFYING THE CONVENTION FOR THE SURRENDER OF CRIMINALS BETWEEN THE UNITED STATES AND THE KING OF FRANCE, SIGNED AT WASHINGTON, NOV. 9, 1843, BY THE SECRETARY OF STATE AND THE MINISTER PLENIPOTENAIRY AD INTERIM FROM THE FRENCH GOVERNMENT TO THE UNITED STATES.
TO POSTPONE ALL PREVIOUS ORDERS, AND CONSIDER THE BILL H.R.1 (APP. 2/16/1844, 5 STAT. L. 651), REFUNDING THE FINE IMPOSED ON GENERAL JACKSON AT NEW ORLEANS.

TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF HENRY A. WISE, OF VIRGINIA, TO BE ENVOY EXTRAORDINARY AND MINISTER PLENIPOTENTIARY OF THE UNITED STATES NEAR HIS MAJESTY THE EMPEROR OF BRAZIL, IN PLACE OF GEORGE H. PROFFIT, WHOSE NOMINATION WAS REJECTED BY THE SENATE.

TO AMEND THE MOTION THAT THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY BE REMOVED FROM THE PROCEEDINGS, PAPERS, EVIDENCE AND SPEECHES AND VOTE OF THE SENATE ON THE NOMINATION OF DAVID HENSHAW OF MASS. FOR APPOINTMENT AS SECRETARY OF THE NAVY, BY LIMITING THE REMOVAL OF SUCH INJUNCTION TO THE VOTE ONLY ON SUCH NOMINATION.

TO AMEND THE MOTION RELATIVE TO THE NOMINATION OF DAVID HENSHAW OF MASS. AS SECRETARY OF THE NAVY (IN PLACE OF ABEL P. UPSHUR, RESIGNED), BY ADDING AFTER DAVID HENSHAW THE NAMES OF GEORGE H. PROFFIT, ISSAC HALL, JAMES M. PORTER, *****MISSING TEXT***** ITY TO VOTE ON NOMINATION OF THESE MEN IN ADDITION TO DAVID HENSHAW.
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 10, (APP. 6/17/1844 5 STAT. L. 672), MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE INSANE ASYLUM IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA.
TO AMEND H.R. 1 BY RELIEVING THE HON. DOMINICK A. HALL OF PERSONAL BLAME FOR IMPOSING SAID FINE.  (P. 267)
TO ORDER A THIRD READING OF H.R. 1.  (P. 274)
TO TABLE THE BILL S. 15, MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR REPAIRING AND REPAVING A PORTION OF PENNSYLVANIA AVENUE IN WASHINGTON, D.C.
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF S. 15.  (P. 282)
TO PASS S. 15.  (P. 298)

TO AMEND THE AMENDMENT TO BILL S. 46, MAKING COMPENSATION TO PENSION AGENTS, THIS AMENDMENT EXCLUDING FROM THE BENEFITS OF THE BILL, SUCH AGENTS WHO MAY BECOME CONNECTED AS OFFICERS, AGENTS, ATTORNEYS, OR DIRECTORS OF BANKS OR BANKING CORPORATIONS.  (P. 299)
TO AMEND S. 46, BY REDUCING COMPENSATIONS OF AGENTS FROM $1,000 TO $500.  (P. 299)
TO ORDER ENFROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF S. 46.  (P. 300)
TO PASS THE BILL S. 75, AUTHORIZING THE TRANSFER TO THE STATE OF MARYLAND, ON CERTAIN CONDITIONS, THE STOCK HELD BY THE UNITED STATES IN THE CHESAPEAKE AND OHIO CANAL. (P. 327)

TO AMEND THE BILL S. 56, TO AFFORD RELIEF TO CERTAIN CONTRACTORS WITH THE GOVERNMENT, BY AUTHORIZING THE EXTENSION OF A CERTAIN CONTRACT WITH THE TREDAGAR IRON CO. OF RICHMOND, MADE ON JULY 20TH, 1842, FOR FURNISHING ONE HUNDRED 32 LB. CANNONS WITH SHOT, UPON TERMS DEEMED JUST AND EQUITABLE BY THE SECRETARY OF THE NAVY.  (P. 342)

TO AMEND THE BILL S. 56, TO AFFORD RELIEF TO CERTAIN CONTRACTORS WITH THE GOVERNMENT, BY ELIMINATING A PROVISION IN THE THIRD SECTION GIVING THE SECRETARY OF THE NAVY POWER TO MODIFY TERMS OF CONTRACT.  (P. 342)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 7, RELATIVE TO THE OFFICE OF SURVEYOR GENERAL OF OHIO, INDIANA AND MICHIGAN.  (P. 347)
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF HARVEY CHAPIN TO BE DEPUTY POSTMASTER AT SPRINGFIELD, MASS. (IN PLACE OF SOLOMON WARRINER, REMOVED).
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF ENOCH C. CHAPMAN, TO BE DEPUTY POSTMASTER AT NORWICH, CONN. (APP. DURING THE RECESS OF THE SENATE, IN PLACE OF S.M. DOWNER, REMOVED).
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF DANA WINSLOW TO BE DEPUTY POSTMASTER AT BURLINGTON, VT. (APPOINTED DURING RECESS OF THE SENATE, IN PLACE OF HENRY STACY, REMOVED).
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF EBENEZER H. STACY TO BE COLLECTOR OF THE CUSTOMS FOR THE DISTRICT OF GLOUCESTER, MASS., IN PLACE OF LEVI LINCOLN, REMOVED.

TO AMEND THE BILL S. 33, GRANTING A CERTIAN SECTION OF LAND TO AID IN THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE FOX AND WISCONSIN RIVERS AND TO CONNECT THE SAME BY A CANAL IN THE TERRITORY OF WISCONSIN, BY ELIMINATING THE PROVISION GIVING THE RIGHT TO THE SECRETARY OF TREASURY TO SELECT VACANT LANDS IN LIEU OF LANDS ALREADY SOLD TO PURCHASERS AND APPROPRIATED BY THIS ACT FOR THE CANAL AND RIVERS.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF JOHN CAIN TO BE DEPUTY POSTMASTER AT INDIANAPOLIS, INDIANA, APPOINTED DURING THE RECESS OF THE SENATE, IN PLACE OF JOSEPH M. MOORE, REMOVED.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF DANIEL C. WESTON TO BE DEPUTY POSTMASTER AT AUGUSTA, MAINE, APPOINTED DURING THE RECESS OF THE SENATE, IN PLACE OF R.F. PERKINS, REMOVED.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF ANSON G. CHANDLER, TO BE COLLECTOR OF THE CUSTOMS FOR THE DISTRICT OF PASSAMQUADDY, MAINE, IN PLACE OF J.C. NOYES, REMOVED.
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF ROBERT RANTOUL, JR. TO BE COLLECTOR OF THE CUSTOMS FOR THE DISTRICT OF BOSTON AND CHARLESTOWN, MASS. (VICE LEVI LINCOLN, REMOVED).

TO AMEND S. 33, BY PROVIDING NOT TO DEDUCT THE 320,000 ACRES APPROPRIATED TO WISCONSIN FROM THE 500,000 ACRES APPROPRIATED IN ANOTHER ACT, SO THAT WIS. RECEIVES A TOTAL LAND ALLOTMENT OF 820,000 ACRES.
TO AMEND S. 33, BY A PROVISION THAT THIS ACT IS NOT TO BECOME EFFECTIVE UNLESS WISCONSIN SIGNIFIES ITS APPROVAL OF SAID ACT WITHIN TWELVE MONTHS.  (P. 390)
TO TABLE THE BILL H.R. 18, TO REPEAL CERTAIN SECTIONS OF AN ACT TO APPROPRIATE THE PROCEEDS OF THE SALES OF THE PUBLIC LANDS, AND TO GRANT PRE-EMPTION RIGHTS.  (P. 391)
TO AMEND S. 33, BY PROPOSING TO GRANT TO THE TERRITORY OF WISCONSIN 320,000 ACRES OF LAND IN ADDITION TO THE ORIGINAL GRANT OF 500,000 ACRES PROPOSED IN THIS BILL.
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF S. 33.  (P. 416)

TO ADOPT A RESOLUTION DIRECTING THE PRESIDENT TO GIVE NOTICE TO THE BRITISH GOVERNMENT OF THE DESIRE OF THE UNITED STATES TO ABROGATE THE 3RD ARTICLE OF THE TREATY RELATIVE TO THE OCCUPATION OF THE OREGON TERRITORY.  (P. 418)

TO AGREE TO THE AMENDMENT TO THE BILL H.R. 60, (APP. 4/30/1844, 5 STAT. L. 656), MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE PAYMENT OF REVOLUTIONARY AND OTHER PENSIONS FOR FISCAL 1845; SAID AMENDMENT SEEKING TO ELIMINATE PAYMENT OF PENSIONS TO ANY PERSON EMPLOYED OR OTHERWISE IN THE SERVICE OF THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 418)

TO CONCUR TO THE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 60, WHICH SEEKS TO ELIMINATE THE PROVISION GIVING A PERSON IN SERVICE OF ARMY OR NAVY A PENSION ONLY IF HIS DISABILITY FORCED HIS EMPLOYMENT IN A LOWER GRADE.  (P. 421)
TO TABLE THE RESOLUTION PROPOSING THE APPOINTMENT OF AN ADDITIONAL STANDING COMMITTEE OF FIVE TO BE KNOWN AS STANDING COMMITTEE ON TERRITORIES.  (P. 428)

TO AMEND THE BILL S. 51, A BILL TO REDUCE THE POSTAGE RATES, LIMIT THE FRANKING PRIVILEGE AND PREVENT FRAUDS ON THE REVENUES OF THE POST OFFICE DEPT., BY A PROPOSAL TO INCREASE FROM 100 TO 750 MILES, THE DISTANCE PERMITTED FOR A FIVE CENT POSTAGE RATE.  (P. 470)
TO AMEND S. 51, BY AUTHORIZING THE FRANKING OF DOCUMENTS WHICH HAVE BEEN OR MAY BE, PRINTED BY ORDER OF EITHER HOUSE OF CONGRESS.  (P. 470)
TO PASS THE BILL H.R. 30, (APP. 4/12/1844, 5 STAT. L. 655) TO MAKE APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE SUPPORT OF THE MILITARY ACADEMY FOR FISCAL 1845.  (P. 474)
TO AMEND THE 1845 FORTIFICATION BILL, H.R. 61 (APP. 5/31/1844, 5 STAT. L. 658), BY INCREASING THE APPROPRIATION FROM $40,000 TO $55,000 FOR FORT LIVINGSTON IN LOUISIANA.

TO AMEND THE BILL S. 18 (APP. 6/15/1844, 5 STAT. 665) ESTABLISHING A NAVY YARD AND DEPOT AT OR NEAR MEMPHIS, TENN. AND APPROPRIATING $100,000 FOR THAT PURPOSE, SAID AMENDMENT AUTHORIZING THE PRESIDENT TO APPOINT A NAVAL OFFICER AND AN ENGINEER TO SURVEY AND SELECT A SITE AND REPORT THEIR FINDINGS TO CONGRESS, APPROPRIATING $5,000 FOR SURVEY COST, AND REWORDING THE TITLE OF THE BILL.  (P. 508)
TO PASS THE BILL S. 18, (APP. 6/15/1844, 5 STAT. 665), TO ESTABLISH A NAVY YARD AND DEPOT AT OR ADJACENT TO MEMPHIS, TENNESSEE.  (P. 511)
TO AMEND S. 51, BY A PROPOSAL TO TAKE AWAY THE PERSONAL FRANKING PRIVILEGE OF MEMBERS OF CONGRESS.  (P. 521)

TO AMEND S. 51, BY A PROVISION THAT IN LIEU OF PRESENT PRIVILEGE TO MEMBERS OF CONGRESS TO SEND COMMUNICATIONS THROUGH THE MAILS FREE OF POSTAGE, THAT EACH MEMBER BE FURNISHED WITH FIVE FREE STAMPS OR ENVELOPES PER DAY OF SESSION OF CONGRESS, WITHIN CERTAIN LIMITATIONS.  (P. 526)
TO AMEND S. 51, BY A PROPOSAL TO MAKE FIVE CENTS THE UNIFORM RATE FOR POSTAGE FOR ALL DISTANCES.  (P. 526)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 84, TO PURCHASE CERTAIN COPIES OF THE HISTORY OF OREGON, CALIFORNIA AND OTHER TERRITORIES ON THE NORTH AND WEST COAST OF NORTH AMERICA.  (P. 532)
TO AMEND S. 51, BY SEEKING TO ESTABLISH RATES BASED ON DISTANCE TRANSMITTED, FOR MAILING MATTER NOT EXCEEDING ONE-HALF OUNCE.  (P. 532)
TO AMEND S. 51, BY MAKING THE FIVE CENT POSTAGE ZONE COVER FROM 30 TO 100 MILES INSTEAD OF 30 TO 180 MILES, AND THE TEN CENT ZONE FROM 100 TO 300 MILES, INSTEAD OF 180 TO 300 MILES.  (P. 532)
TO CONSIDER S. 51.

TO RESUME CONSIDERATION OF THE RESOLUTIONS IN RELATION TO THE BILL S. 19, TO REVIVE THE ACT OF MAR. 2, 1833, USUALLY CALLED THE COMPROMISE ACT, AND TO MODIFY THE EXISTING DUTIES UPON FOREIGN IMPORTS, SAID RESOLUTIONS PROVIDING FOR THE INDEFINITE POSTPONEMENT OF THE TARIFF BILL.
TO AMEND S. 51, BY SEEKING TO GIVE CONGRESSMEN AUTHORITY TO FRANK AND RECEIVE POSTAGE FREE LETTERS IN MANUSCRIPT DURING THE RECESS OF CONGRESS.  (P. 555)
TO AMEND S. 51, BY PROVIDING THAT ALL MEMBERS OF CONGRESS BE PLACED ON AN EQUAL BASIS ON THE MATTER OF FREE STAMPS, BY REMOVING ALL LIMITATIONS AS TO DISTANCES.  (P. 554)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF S. 51.  (P. 556)
TO PASS S. 51.  (P. 562)
THAT WHEN THE SENATE ADJOURNS TODAY, IT WILL MEET AGAIN ON FRIDAY NEXT.
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 35, MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE CONTINUATION OF THE CUMBERLAND ROAD THROUGH THE STATES OF OHIO, INDIANA AND ILLINOIS.  (P. 576)

TO AMEND THE BILL S. 101, SUPPLEMENTAL TO THE ACT TO REGULATE THE PAY OF THE NAVY, BY ELIMINATING THE 2ND SECTION PROVIDING THAT WHERE ANY VESSEL OF THE UNITED STATES IS LOST BY SHIPWRECK OR OTHERWISE, COMPENSATION SHALL BE GIVEN TO THE OFFICERS AND CREWS OF SAID SHIPS FOR LOSSES SUSTAINED AND ESTABLISHED BY THEM, ALSO DETAILING AMOUNTS PROPOSED TO BE GIVEN TO EACH INDIVIDUAL ACCORDING TO HIS GRADE.
TO AMEND S. 101 BY EXCLUDING FROM SUCH PROPOSED COMPENSATION, ALL CASES IN WHICH A VESSEL IS SUFFERED BY ITS CREW TO BE CAPTURED BY AN ENEMY.  (P. 576)
TO PASS THE BILL S. 35, MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE CONTINUATION OF THE CUMBERLAND ROAD THROUGH THE STATES OF OHIO, INDIANA AND ILLINOIS.  (P. 580)
TO PASS S. 101.  (P. 580)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 90, GRANTING A RIGHT OF WAY THROUGH THE STATE OF ILLINOIS TO THE GREAT WESTERN RAILROAD FOR RAILROAD CONSTRUCTION.

TO AMEND AMENDMENT TO THE BILL S. 86, (APP. 6/17/1844, 5 STAT. L. 677), EXTENDING THE CHARTERS OF THE BANKS IN THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA, BY MAKING "ALL STOCKHOLDERS LIABLE, INDIVIDUALLY AS WELL AS COLLECTIVELY, IN CASE OF BANK FAILURE.  (P. 585)

TO AMEND S. 86, BY PROVIDING THAT IN CASE OF BANK FAILURE, THE DIRECTORS OR THE STOCKHOLDERS, COPARTNERSHIP OR BODY POLITE, MAY BE HELD LIABLE FOR NOT EXCEEDING TWICE THE AMOUNT OF THEIR SHARES IN SAID BANK AND, IN CASE OF REFUSAL OF SAID HOLDERS OF STOCK TO ACCEPT THIS PROVISION, THE AFFAIRS OF THE BANK ARE TO BE WOUND UP AND FURTHER, THAT EACH BANK SHALL KEEP AN ACCURATE LIST OF THE NAMES OF STOCKHOLDERS AND AMOUNTS OF STOCK OWNED BY THEM, TO BE POSTED FOR PUBLIC INSPECTION AND PUBLISHED IN NEWSPAPERS EVERY THREE MONTHS.  (P. 586)

TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION REPRIMANDING BENJAMIN TAPPAN FOR VIOLATING SENATE RULE 36, SO AS TO ALSO REPRIMAND HIM FOR FURNISHING FOR PUBLICATION DOCUMENTS DIRECTED BY THE SENATE TO BE PRINTED IN CONFIDENCE.
TO AGREE TO THE AMENDED AMENDMENT, REPRIMANDING BENJAMIN TAPPAN FOR VIOLATING SENATE RULE 36, FOR FURNISHING FOR PUBLICATION, DOCUMENTS DIRECTED BY THE SENATE TO BE PRINTED IN CONFIDENCE.
TO PASS THE RESOLUTION AS AMENDED, REPRIMANDING BENJAMIN TAPPAN FOR VIOLATING RULE 36, FURNISHING FOR PUBLICATION, DOCUMENTS DIRECTED BY THE SENATE TO BE PRINTED IN CONFIDENCE.
TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION THAT, IN CONSIDERATION OF THE ACKNOWLEDGEMENT AND APOLOGY TENDERED BY BENJAMIN TAPPAN FOR HIS OFFENCE, NO FURTHER CENSURE BE INFLICTED UPON HIM.

TO PASS THE RESOLUTION AMENDING THE RULES SO THAT ANY OFFICER OR MEMBER OF THE SENATE CONVICTED OF DISCLOSING FOR PUBLICATION ANY WRITTEN OR PRINTED MATTER DIRECTED TO BE HELD IN CONFIDENCE, SHALL BE LIABLE TO DISMISSAL, OR EXPULSION.
TO PASS THE BILL S. 73, N.P., FOR PAYMENT FOR SERVICES TO THE MILITIA OF VERMONT AT THE BATTLE OF PLATTSBURG. (P. 589)
TO PROCEED WITH EXECUTIVE BUSINESS.  (P. 589)

TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION TO REMOVE THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY FROM THE TREATY WITH TEXAS AND THE MESSAGES AND DOCUMENTS BE PRINTED IN CONFIDENCE FOR USE IN THE SENATE, THE TREATIES AND DOCUMENTS HAVING BEEN SURREPUITIONSLY MADE PUBLIC.

TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF S. 86 (JOURNAL DESCRIPTION) TO CONCUR IN THE AMENDED AMENDMENT TO S. 86 WHICH PROVIDES FOR THE APPOINTMENT OF THREE TRUSTEES OR RECEIVERS BY THE CIRCUIT COURT FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA UPON THE APPLICATION OF BANKS FOR RECEIVERSHIP. (GLOBE DISCRIPTION).  (P. 593)

TO AMEND THE BILL H.R. 36, (APP. 6/15/1844, 5 STAT. L. 677) GRANTING RELIEF TO THE WIDOWS AND ORPHANS OF OFFICERS, SEAMEN AND MARINES OF CERTAIN SHIPS, BY DENYING RELIEF TO CHILDREN WHEN THERE IS NO LIVING WIDOW.  (P. 593)
TO POSTPONE, FOR ONE WEEK, CONSIDERATION OF THE TREATY OF ANNEXATION OF TEXAS.
TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION POSTPONING THE CONSIDERATION OF THE TEXAS TREATY TO 1ST DAY OF JUNE NEXT.

TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION MAKING THE TREATY OF ANNEXATION OF TEXAS THE SPECIAL ORDER, IN THE EXECUTIVE SESSION FOR, THURSDAY NEXT AT TWO O'CLOCK INSTEAD OF ONE O'CLOCK P.M. AND EVERY SUCCEEDING DAY AT THE SAME HOUR, UNTIL DISPOSED OF.

TO PASS THE BILL S. 94 (APP. 6/12/1844, 5 STAT. L. 662), AMENDING AN ACT ENTITLED, AN ACT TO REORGANIZE THE GENERAL LAND OFFICE (JOURNAL DESCRIPTION). TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 94 (APP. 6/12/1844, 5 STAT. L. 662) AMENDING AN ACT ENTITLED AN ACT TO REORGANIZE THE GENERAL LAND OFFICE. (GLOBE DESCRIPTION).
TO AMEND AMENDMENT TO RESOLUTION RELATING TO THE ANNEXATION OF TEXAS, BY ELIMINATING THE WORDS "THAT THE WILL OF THE PEOPLE OUGHT TO BE CONSULTED".
TO ADJOURN, IN ORDER TO PREVENT FURTHER ACTION ON THE RESOLUTION RELATING TO THE ANNEXATION OF TEXAS.
TO AMEND AMENDMENT TO RESOLUTION RELATING TO THE ANNEXATION OF TEXAS, BY REMOVING THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY EXCEPT ALL MESSAGES AND DOCUMENTS RECEIVED THIS DAY.
TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT BY PROVIDING THAT A REASONABLE TIME SHOULD BE GIVEN TO HEAR FROM THE PEOPLE, AFTER THIS PUBLICATION, BEFORE THE FINAL DECISION OF THE SENATE UPON THE TEXAS TREATY.
TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION, BY REMOVING THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY ON ALL MESSAGES AND DOCUMENTS FOR PUBLICATION RELATIVE TO ANNEXATION OF TEXAS.
TO AGREE TO THE RESOLUTION AS AMENDED, REMOVING THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY ON ALL MESSAGES AND DOCUMENTS FOR PUBLICATION RELATIVE TO THE TEXAS TREATY.
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 66, RELATING TO CLAIM OF HENRY GARDNER AND OTHERS, DIRECTORS OF NEW ENGLAND LAND COMPANY ASSOCIATION.  (P. 599)
TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE AGREEING TO RESOLUTION REMOVING INJUNCTION OF SECRECY ON ALL DOCUMENTS AND MESSAGES FOR PUBLICATION FROM THE TREATY OF ANNEXATION OF TEXAS.

TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION TO TEXAS TREATY, BY INCLUDING IN THE PRINTING OF 20,000 COPIES OF DOCUMENTS AND TREATY, A LETTER OF MR. WEBSTER, AS SECRETARY OF STATE, TO MR. THOMPSON, OUR MINISTER AT MEXICO, DATED JULY 8, 1842.

TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION RELATIVE TO TEXAS TREATY, BY INCLUDING IN THE PRINTING OF 20,000 COPIES OF DOCUMENTS AND TREATY, ALL CORRESPONDENCE OF MR. CLAY AND VAN BUREN WITH OUR MINISTERS AT MEXICO RELATIVE TO ANNEXATION OF TEXAS TO THE UNITED STATES.
TO CONSIDER THE RESOLUTION RELATING TO ANNEXATION OF TEXAS, THAT FURTHER PROCEEDINGS ON THE TEXAS TREATY BE HAD WITH OPEN DOORS.
TO PASS THE BILL S. 66, N.P. RELATING TO CLAIM OF HENRY GARDNER AND OTHERS, DIRECTORS OF NEW ENGLAND LAND COMPANY ASSOCIATION.  (P. 603)

TO AGREE TO HAVE PRINTED IN CONFIDENCE PRESIDENT JOHN TYLER'S MESSAGE RECOMMENDING IMMEDIATE ANNEXATION OF TEXAS, WITH PAPERS AND LETTERS SUPPORTING HIS STAND LEST TEXAS BE LOST FOREVER TO ENGLAND, FOR USE OF THE SENATE ONLY.

TO REFER THE REPORT FROM THE SECRETARY OF STATE, WITH SUNDRY PAPERS, IN ANSWER TO RESOLUTION OF THE SENATE OF MAY 13, RELATING TO A SUPPOSED ARMISTICE BETWEEN THE REPUBLIC OF MEXICO AND TEXAS, FOR USE OF THE SENATE.
TO TABLE THE RESOLUTION TO ADJOURN CONGRESS, SINE DIE. (P. 607)
TO ADJOURN, MATION MADE DURING CONSIDERATION OF A RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY BE REMOVED ON ALL MESSAGES AND DOCUMENTS FOR PUBLICATION RELATIVE TO THE TEXAS TREATY.
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 26, N.P. WHICH AUTHORIZES PERSONS TO WHOM RESERVATIONS OF LAND HAVE BEEN OR SHALL BE MADE UNDER INDIAN TREATIES TO ALIENATE THE SAME IN FEE.
TO AMEND RESOLUTION TO TEXAS TREATY, BY REMOVING THE INJUNCTION OF SECRECY ON THE TEXAS TREATY, AND ALL OTHER SPEECHES ON THE SAME SUBJECT AS SOON AS DELIVERED.
TO POSTPONE INDEFINITELY, CONSIDERATION OF THE BILL H.R. 256, TO REGULATE THE PAY OF THE ARMY.  (P. 615)
TO CONSENT TO THE NOMINATION OF GEORGE C. WASHINGTON AND JOHN T. MASON TO BE CHEROKEE COMMISSIONERS REPLACING RESPECTIVELY, JOHN H. EATON AND EDWARD B. HUBLEY, BOTH REMOVED.

TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION AS AMENDED, THAT 1,000 COPIES OF THE MAP OF TEXAS, LATELY SENT BY THE EXECUTIVE, TO THE SENATE, BE PUBLISHED FOR THE USE OF THE SENATE; THE AMENDED RESOLUTION TO PROVIDE FOR LITHOGRAPHING, RATHER THAN PRINTING THESE MAPS, AND THAT THEY BE HALF THE SIZE OF THAT SENT, PROVIDED THE COST DOES NOT EXCEED $200.
TO REQUEST THE HOUSE TO RETURN TO THE SENATE FOR FURTHER CONSIDERATION, THE BILL H.R. 256, REGULATING THE PAY OF THE ARMY.  (P. 623)
TO POSTPONE FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF THE RESOLUTION PROVIDING FOR THE ADJOURNMENT OF CONGRESS UNTIL FRIDAY NEXT. (P. 623)

TO AMEND THE BILL S. 109, N.P. GRANTING PENSIONS TO WIDOWS AND ORPHANS OF NAVAL OFFICERS, SEAMEN AND MARINES, BY A PROPOSAL THAT SUCH PENSIONS SHALL INCLUDE WIDOWS AND ORPHANS OF SAID NAVAL OFFICERS, SEAMEN AND MARINES WHO SHALL HAVE DIED BY REASON OF DISEASE.  (P. 628)

TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 109, AS AMENDED, GRANTING PENSIONS TO THE WIDOWS OF OFFICERS, SEAMEN OR MARINES WHO HAVE BEEN KILLED, OR DIED BY REASON OF WOUNDS RECEIVED IN THE LINE OF THEIR DUTY, OR WHO HAVE DIED BY REASON OF DISEASE CONTRACTED, OR BY DROWNING, OR OTHERWISE.  (P. 628)

TO AMEND THE BILL S. 143, RELIEVING THE HEIRS OF ROBERT FULTON AND APPROPRIATING $76,300 AS A BALANCE DUE HIS REPRESENTATIVES, AFTER DEDUCTING $45,000 ADVANCED TO HIM AS BEING PAYMENT IN FULL OF HIS CLAIM, ON ACCOUNT OF HIS STEAMER, VESUVIUS AND THE USE OF HIS SERVICES IN CONSTRUCTION OF THE FRIGATE FULTON, BY ADDING A STIPULATION THAT SAID PAYMENT IS ALSO FOR THE GREAT BENEFITS CONFERRED ON THE COUNTRY BY MR. TO AMEND THE AMENDMENT TO THE BILL S. 46, (APP. 3/3/1845, 5 STAT. L. 748), REDUCING THE RATES OF POSTAGE, LIMITING THE USE AND CORRECTING THE ABUSE OF THE FRANKING PRIVILEGE, AND PREVENTING FRAUDS ON THE POST OFFICE REVENUES, BY DECREASING THE RATES OF POSTAGE PROPOSED.
TO AMEND S. 46, TO INCREASE FROM 100 TO 250 MILES THE DISTANCE TO WHICH THE FIVE CENT POSTAGE EXTENDS.

TO AMEND S. 46 TO ELIMINATE THE FIRST SECTION OF THE BILL AND TO PROVIDE THAT 1) POSTAGE RATES ARE DETERMINED ACCORDING TO BOTH DISTANCE TRANSMITTED AND WEIGHT OF THE LETTER; 2) IT SHALL BE UNLAWFUL TO ENCLOSE MORE THAN ONE LETTER TO DIFFERENT PERSONS IN ONE ENVELOPE; 3) A FIXED RATE OF POSTAGE SHALL BE SET FOR LETTERS DEPOSITED IN A POST OFFICE FOR DELIVERY, RATHER THAN TRANSMISSION; 4) AND THAT ADVERTISED LETTERS SHALL BE CHARGED A FIXED RATE OF POSTAGE IN ADDITION TO ADVERTIZING COSTS.

TO AMEND S. 46 TO PROVIDE EACH MEMBER OF CONGRESS AND THE DELEGATES FROM THE TERRITORIES WITH FIVE FREE COVERS EACH DAY TO SEND THROUGHT THE MAIL; THESE COVERS ARE TO BE IN LIEU OF THE PRESENT FRANKING PRIVILEGE.  (P. 221)

TO AMEND S. 46 TO PROVIDE EXEMPTION FOR MEMBERS OF CONGRESS, DELEGATES FROM TERRITORIES, THE PRESIDING OFFICERS OF THE TWO HOUSES OF CONGRESS, THE SECRETARY OF THE SENATE, AND THE CLERK OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES FROM THE REPEAL OF ANY LAWS PRESENTLY GRANTING THE FRANKING PRIVILEGE.

TO AMEND S. 46 TO ELIMINATE THE FRANKING PRIVILEGE EXTENDED TO DELEGATES OF CONGRESS, CLERKS OF THE HOUSE AND SECRETARY OF THE SENATE, THEREBY PLACING ALL GOVERNMENT ADMINISTRATION EMPLOYEES ON THE SAME FOOTING.  (P. 234)
TO AMEND S. 46 TO ALLOW PUBLISHERS OF NEWSPAPERS AND PERIODICALS THE RIGHT OF TRANSMITTING THEM TO THEIR SUBSCRIBERS IN ANY MANNER THEY CHOOSE.  (P. 234)
TO REFER TO THE COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN RELATIONS, THE BILL S. 118, TO PROVIDE FOR THE ANNEXATION OF TEXAS TO THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 248)
TO AMEND THE AMENDMENT TO S. 46 TO DENY MEMBERS OF CONGRESS THE PRIVILEGE OF FRANKING PERSONAL LETTERS.  (P. 252)
TO AMEND S. 46 TO PERMIT THE MEMBERS OF CONGRESS THE PRIVILEGE OF FRANKING THEIR WRITTEN LETTERS NOT EXCEEDING TWO OUNCES IN WEIGHT, AND PRINTED COPIES OF SPEECHES DELIVERED IN CONGRESS.
TO CONCUR IN THE AMENDMENT TO S. 46, SAID AMENDMENT TO STRIKE OUT SECTION 9 OF THE BILL. SECTION 9 PROVIDES FOR THE ABOLITION OF THE FRANKING PRIVILEGE.

TO CONCUR IN THE AMENDMENT TO S. 46 TO GIVE THE POSTMASTER GENERAL AUTHORITY ONLY OVER PUBLICATIONS SENT THROUGH THE MAIL, AND TO LEAVE PUBLISHERS FREE TO SEND THEM WHERE, WHEN AND HOW THEY PLEASE.  (P. 253)
TO AMEND S. 46 TO ESTABLISH A UNIFORM RATE OF 5 CENTS POSTAGE FOR ALL DISTANCES.  (P. 253)
TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE BY WHICH AN AMENDMENT TO S. 46, TO LIMIT THE RATES ALLOWED TO RAILROADS TRANSPORTING MAIL, WAS AGREED TO.  (P. 254)
TO ADOPT THE AMENDMENT TO S. 46 TO ALLOW MEMBERS OF CONGRESS TO MAIL THEIR OWN LETTERS FREE DURING THE WHOLE YEAR.

TO AMEND S. 46, BY PROVIDING THAT WHEN THE COMPENSATION OF THE DEPUTY POSTMASTERS FALLS SHORT OF THAT WHICH THEY RECEIVED IN 1844, AS LONG AS IT DOES NOT EXCEED $50, THE DIFFERENCE SHALL BE MADE GOOD OUT OF THE POSTAGE HE RE- CEIVES.  THIS IS EFFECTIVE EVEN IF THE DEFICIENCY AMOUNTS TO THE WHOLE POSTAGE HE RECEIVES, BUT NEVER TO EXCEED HIS RECEIPTS.  (P. 257)
TO AMEND S. 46 BY INSERTING THE CLAUSE, "THAT THE RATE OF POSTAGE ON LETTERS CONVEYED BY MAIL ANY DISTANCE NOT EXCEEDING 50 MILES SHALL BE 3 CENTS".  (P. 258)
TO PASS S. 46 WITH THE AMENDMENT PROVIDING FOR THE ELIMINATION OF THE 16TH SECTION AND EXTENDING THE FRANKING PRIVILEGE TO EX-PRESIDENTS.  (P. 264)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL (S. 47, TO PROVIDE FOR ASCERTAINING OF CLAIMS OF AMERICAN CITIZENS FOR SPOLIATION PRIOR TO JULY 31, 1801. (P. 267)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 75, PROVIDING FOR A FREE BRIDGE ACROSS THE EASTERN BRANCH OF THE POTOMAC RIVER IN THE CITY OF WASHINGTON.  (P. 267)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL H.R. 440, (APP. 2/20/1845, 5 STAT. L. 722), FOR THE PURCHASE OF COPIES OF GREENBOWS HISTORY OF OREGON.  (P. 272)

TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 119, TO PROVIDE FOR THE PURCHASE AND DISTRIBUTION OF THE REPORTS OF THE DECISIONS OF THE SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES AMONG THE SEVERAL STATES AND TERRITORIES. (P. 272)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF THE BILL S. 77, AUTHORIZING THE APPOINTMENT OF ASSISTANT SURGEONS AND PURSERS IN THE NAVY.
TO POSTPONE INDEFINITELY, FURTHER CONSIDERATION OF THE BILL S. 63, CONFIRMING TITLE TO A TRACT OF LAND IN THE TERRITORY OF IOWA TO THE HEIRS OF JULIAN DUBUQUE.
TO PASS S. 119 AS AMENDED, A BILL PROVIDING FOR THE PURCHASE OF UNITED STATES SURPREME COURT DECISIONS FOR DISTRIBUTION AMONG THE SEVERAL STATES AND TERRITORIES. (P. 278)

TO REFER TO THE COMMITTEE ON JUDICIARY THE BILL H.R. 497, (APP. 3/3/1845, 76 STAT. L. 789) AND (48-5 STAT. L. 742) TO PROVIDE FOR THE ADMISSION OF THE STATES OF IOWA AND FLORIDA INTO THE UNION.  (P. 287)
TO POSTPONE UNTIL WEDNESDAY NEXT THE CONSIDERATION OF THE RESOLUTION PROVIDING THAT THE DAILY HOUR OF THE MEETING OF THE SENATE SHALL BE AT 11 O'CLOCK.  (P. 292)
TO AMEND THE RESOLUTION WHICH FIXED THE HOUR FOR THE MEETING OF THE SENATE AT ELEVEN O'CLOCK, THE AMENDMENT TO CHANGE THE HOUR TO TEN O'CLOCK.  (P. 308)
TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION AS AMENDED, FIXING THE HOUR FOR THE MEETING OF THE SENATE AT TEN O'CLOCK INSTEAD OF ELEVEN O'CLOCK.  (P. 308)
TO RECONSIDER THE RESOLUTION FIXING THE HOUR OF MEETING OF THE SENATE AT 10 O'CLOCK.  (P. 314)
TO ADOPT A RESOLUTION THAT THE SPECIAL ORDER OF THE DAY BE HEREAFTER CALLED BY THE CHAIR AT TWELVE O'CLOCK.  (P. 315)

TO ADJOURN, IN ORDER TO TERMINATE FOR THE TIME BEING, THE DEBATE ON THE RESOLUTION H.J. RES. 46, (APP. 3/1/1845, C8-5 STAT. L. 797), PROVIDING FOR THE ANNEXATION OF TEXAS TO THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 330)
TO PASS THE BILL H.R. 493 (APP. 3/3/1845, 5 STAT. L. 742), TO MAKE APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE SUPPORT OF THE MILITARY ACADEMY AT WEST POINTE FOR FISCAL 1846.  (P. 332)
TO PROCEED TO CONSIDERATION OF H.J.R. 46.  (P. 334)
TO ADJOURN, DURING DEBATE ON THE RESOLUTION H.J.R. 46. (P. 352)
TO ADJOURN BECAUSE OF THE LATENESS OF THE HOUR, DURING DEBATE ON THE RESOLUTION H.J.R. 46.  (P. 352)

TO CONSIDER THE FIRST DIVISION OF THE AMENDMENT OF H.J.R. 46 TO ADMIT THE STATE OF TEXAS AND ANY OTHER TERRITORY CONTAINED IN ANY PORTION OF THE PRESENT TERRITORY OF TEXAS, LYING SOUTH 36 DEGREES, 30 MINUTES, NORTH LATITUDE (KNOWN AS THE MISSOURI COMPROMISE LINE), INTO THE UNION WITH OR WITHOUT SLAVERY, AS THE PEOPLE OF EACH STATE MAY DIRECT. (P. 360)
TO CONSIDER THE SECOND DIVISION OF THE AMENDMENT TO H.J.R.46 TO PROVIDE AGAINST THE PUBLIC DEBT OF TEXAS BECOMING A CHARGE UPON THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 361)

TO AMEND H.J.R.46, BY ELIMINATING THE RESOLUTION WHICH REQUESTED THE PRESIDENT TO ORDER NEGOTIATIONS TO BE ENTERED INTO WITH THE GOVERNMENT OF TEXAS, FOR THE PURPOSE OF ANNEXING TEXAS INTO THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 360)

TO AMEND IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, H.J.R.46, AMENDMENT BEING THAT IF THE PRESIDENT OF THE U.S., SHALL DEEM IT ADVISABLE, INSTEAD OF PROCEEDING TO SUBMIT THE FOREGOING RESOLUTION TO THE REPRESENTATIVES OF TEXAS, AS AN OVERTURE ON THE PART OF THE U.S. FOR ADMISSION TO NEGOTIATE WITH THAT REPUBLIC, THEN, BE IT RESOLVED, THAT A STATE BE FORMED OUT OF THE PRESENT REPUBLIC OF TEXAS, AND TO AGREE UPON THE TERMS OF SAID ADMISSION AND CESSION, EITHER BY TREATY TO BE SUBMITTED TO THE SENATE, OR BY ARTICLES TO BE SUBMITTED TO THE HOUSE OF CONGRESS, AS THE PRESIDENT MAY DIRECT.
TO AMEND AN AMENDMENT TO H.J.R.46 TO ELIMINATE THE HOUSE GRANTING THE AUTHORITY TO THE PRESIDENT TO DIRECT THE TWO HOUSES OF CONGRESS IN AGREEING TO THE TERMS OF THE ADMISSION OF TEXAS.  (P. 361)

TO CONCUR IN THE AMENDMENT TO H.J.R.46, AS IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, AMENDMENT PROPOSING THAT THE PRESIDENT MAY, INSTEAD OF PROCEEDING TO SUBMIT THE FOREGOING RESOLUTION TO THE REPUBLIC OF TEXAS, AS AN OVERTURE ON THE PART OF THE UNITED STATES FOR ADMISSION TO NEGOTIATE WITH THAT REPUBLIC, THEN LET IT BE RESOLVED, THAT, A STATE BE FORMED OF THE PRESENT REPUBLIC OF TEXAS, AND THE TERMS OF SAID ADMISSION AND CESSION SHALL BE AGREED UPON EITHER BY TREATYS OR BY ARTICLES.

TO AMEND H.J.R.46 TO PREVENT THE PUBLIC DEBT OF TEXAS FROM BECOMING CHARGED UPON THE UNITED STATES GOVERNMENT, ALSO TO OUTLINE STIPULATIONS FOR ADMISSION TO THE UNION CONCERNING THE FORMATION OF MORE THAN ONE STATE FROM THE TERRITORY OF TEXAS, AND ITS DECISIONS INTO SLAVE-HOLDING AND NON-SLAVE-HOLDING TERRITORY. (JOURNAL VERSION). TO ELIMINATE FROM H.J.R.46 ALL THAT PORTION INSERTED BY THE HOUSE, THUS TO MAKE THE STATE'S ADMISSION INTO THE UNION DEFINITE, AND TO TAKE AWAY THE DISCRETIONARY POWER OF THE PRESIDENT TO HAVE TEXAS ADMITTED BY TREATY IF AGREED TO, BUT IF TO BE ADMITTED BY RESOLUTION, TO REPORT IT BACK TO CONGRESS. (GLOBE VERSION).  (P. 362)

TO AMEND THE AMENDMENT TO H.J.R.46 TO STIPULATE THAT A CERTAIN AREA OF THE TERRITORY OF TEXAS SHALL OR SHALL NOT HAVE SLAVERY AS THE PEOPLE OF THAT TERRITORY DECIDE. ALSO TO PREVENT THE PUBLIC DEBT OF TEXAS FROM BEING CHARGED TO THE UNITED STATES.

TO AMEND H.J.R.46 IN THE FORM OF A SUBSTITUTE, WHICH REQUESTS THE PRESIDENT TO NEGOTIATE WITH TEXAS FOR TRANSFER TO THE UNITED STATES OF THE TERRITORY, WITH ALL RIGHTS, THERETO, THEREBY INCORPORATING THE STATE INTO THE UNION UNDER A TREATY.  (P. 362)

TO AMEND H.J.R. 46, BY AUTHORIZING THE PRESIDENT TO NEGOTIATE WITH MEXICO AND TEXAS FOR ADJUSTING BOUNDARIES AND TO ANNEX TEXAS ON EQUAL FOOTING WITH THE ORIGINAL STATES, AND TO DIVIDE IT EQUALLY AMONG SLAVE-HOLDERS AND NON-SLAVE-HOLDERS; OTHER DETAILS TO COME WITHIN THE SCOPE OF HIS POWER.  (P. 362-3)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H.J.R.46. (P. 362)
TO PASS THE BILL S. 87, ENABLING THE CHICKASAW NATION OF INDIANS TO TRY THE VALIDITY OF THEIR CLAIMS IN THE COURTS OF THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 365)

TO PASS THE BILL S. 84, FOR THE RELIEF OF THE STATE OF MICHIGAN AND CERTAIN RAILROAD COMPANIES, EXTENDING THE TIME ORIGINALLY ALLOWED TO TRANSPORT CERTAIN RAILROAD IRON, WHICH THEY WERE HERETOFORE AUTHORIZED TO INPORT DUTY FREE. (P. 365)

TO POSTPONE THE ORDER OF THE DAY, MADE DURING DEBATE ON THE BILL H.R. 497, (APP. 3/3/1845, C-76-5 STAT. 789) (C-48-5 STAT. 742) PROVIDING FOR THE ADMISSION OF THE STATES OF IOWA AND FLORIDA INTO THE UNION.  (P. 366)

TO CONCUR IN THE AMENDMENT TO THE BILL H.R. 498 (APP. 3/3/1845), MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE CIVIL AND DIPLOMATIC GOVERNMENT EXPENSES FOR FISCAL 1846, WHICH WOULD PROVIDE FOR THE ADJUSTMENT AND SETTLEMENT OF THE APRIL AND JULY INSTALLMENTS OF THE MEXICAN INDEMNITIES IN THE SUM OF $275,000.  (P. 368)

TO CONCUR, UPON RECONSIDERATION, IN THE AMENDMENT APPROVED IN THE COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE, TO THE BILL H.R. 498, (APP. 3/3/1845) WHICH MAKES APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE CIVIL AND DIPLOMATIC EXPENSES OF THE GOVERNMENT FOR FISCAL 1846, SAID AMENDMENT TO AUTHORIZE THE PAYMENT OF THE APR. AND JULY INSTALLMENTS OF THE MEXICAN INDEMNITIES DUE 1844, BY APPROPRIATING $275,000 FOR THE PAYMENT THEREOF, IT APPEARING THAT THIS SUM HAD BEEN DULY PAID TO AN AUTHORIZED AGENT OF THE U.S. GOVERNMENT.  (P. 368)
TO CONCUR IN AMENDMENTS OF THE HOUSE TO S. 46 WHICH CONFIRMS THE RATE OF 5 CENTS POSTAGE FOR DISTANCES WITHIN 300 MILES AND INCREASING THE RATE TO 10 CENTS FOR GREATER DISTANCES.  (P. 376)

TO AGREE TO THE AMENDMENT TO S.46, AS MODIFIED, TO PERMIT THE FRANKING PRIVILEGE, IN RECEIVING AS WELL AS SENDING LETTERS, TO THE SENATORS AND WOULD EXTEND THIS PRIVILEGE TO THE VICE-PRESIDENT.  (P. 376)

TO RECONSIDER THE VOTE CONCURRING IN THE TWO AMENDMENTS TO S.46 FOR THE PURPOSE OF HAVING THE SENATE VOTE AGAIN ON AMENDMENTS WHICH POSTPONE ALL NEW RATES UNTIL JULY 1ST NEXT AND FIXES A RATE OF 5 CENTS FOR 300 MILES AND 10 CENTS FOR ALL GREATER DISTANCES.  (P. 376)

TO TABLE THE RESOLUTION H.J.R.71, (APP. 3/3/1845, 5 STAT. L. 801) TO DIRECT THE SECRETARY OF THE TREASURY TO RETAIN ANY FUNDS TO THOSE STATES WHICH HAVE DEFAULTED IN THEIR INTEREST OR PRINCIPAL ON INVESTMENTS IN THE STOCKS OR BONDS HELD BY THE UNITED STATES IN TRUST.  (P. 377)
TO TABLE H.J.R.71.  (P. 377)
TO ORDER ENGROSSMENT AND THIRD READING OF H.J.R.71. (P. 377)

TO AMEND THE BILL H.R. 497, (APP. 3/3/1845, C 76-5 STAT. 789 C 48-5 STAT. 742) ADMITTING IOWA AND FLORIDA INTO THE UNION, THE AMENDMENT BEING, TO ADD A PROVISO TO THE BILL, THAT AS FAR AS RELATES TO FLORIDA, THIS ACT SHALL NOT BE EFFECTIVE UNTIL THE FOLLOWING CLAUSES ARE ELIMINATED FROM THE CONSTITUTION OF FLORIDA; THE FIRST SECTION: 1) THAT THE GENERAL ASSEMBLY SHALL HAVE NO POWER TO PASS LAWS FOR EMANCIPATION OF SLAVES; AND THE THIRD SECTION 3) THAT THEY HAVE NOT POWER TO PASS LAWS TO PREVENT FREE NEGROES OR OTHER PERSONS OF COLOR, FROM IMIGRATING TO THIS STATE.  (P. 383)
TO PASS H.R. 497.  (P. 383)
TO POSTPONE PREVIOUS ORDERS AND TAKE UP FOR CONSIDERATION, THE BILL, H.R. 439, ORGANIZING A TERRITORIAL GOVERNMENT IN THE TERRITORY OF OREGON.  (P. 388)

TO AMEND THE AMENDMENT TO THE BILL H.R. 491, (APP. 3/3/1845, 5 STAT. 766), WHICH IS THE INDIAN APPROPRIATION BILL FOR FISCAL 1846. SAID AMENDMENT WOULD PROVIDE FOR ONE YEAR, SUBSISTENCE TO THOSE INDIANS WHO HAVE BEEN REMOVED TO RESERVATIONS.  (P. 389)
TO AMEND THE BILL H.R. 491, (APP. 3/3/1845, 5 STAT. 766), THE INDIAN APPROPRIATION BILL TO OUTLINE THE CONDITIONS AND PROCEDURES FOR ISSUING MONEY TO THOSE INDIANS REMOVED TO RESERVATIONS.  (P. 389)

TO ADOPT THE RESOLUTION DIRECTING PAYMENT OUT OF THE CONTINGENT FUND OF THE USUAL EXTRA ALLOWANCES TO THE CLERKS AND OFFICERS OF THE SENATE, THE SAME AMOUNTS RESPECTIVELY AS WERE PAID THEM UNDER A SIMILAR RESOLUTION AT THE LAST SESSION.  (P. 389)
TO TABLE THE MOTION TO PRINT 5000 EXTRA COPIES OF THE REPORT OF THE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY CONCERNING THE INVESTIGATION OF NATURALIZATION LAWS AND THE ABUSES OF THE ELECTIVE FRANCHISE.  (P. 389)
TO MOVE TO PRINT 5,000 EXTRA COPIES OF THE REPORT FROM THE COMMITTEE ON THE JUDICIARY CONCERNING THE INVESTIGATION INTO THE ALLEGED VIOLATIONS OF THE NATURALIZATION AND ELECTION LAWS.  (P. 390)

TO AMEND THE BILL H.R. 502 (APP. 3/3/1845, 5 STAT. 790), MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE NAVAL SERVICE FOR FISCAL 1846, TO PROVIDE COMPENSATION TO THE HEIRS OF ROBERT FULTON FOR HIS CLAIM AGAINST THE UNITED STATES.  (P. 390)

TO AMEND THE BILL H.R. 501 (APP. 3/3/1845, 5 STAT. 745), MAKING APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE SUPPORT OF THE ARMY FOR FISCAL 1846, WHICH AMENDMENT ELIMINATES THE SUM OF $20,000 TO BE EXPENDED UNDER THE DIRECTION OF THE SECRETARY OF WAR, FOR AN ARMORY AT FORT MASSAC IN THE STATE OF ILL.  (P. 391)

TO AMEND THE AMENDMENT TO H.R. 501, TO APPROPRIATE $225,000 FOR THE CONTINUATION OF THE CUMBERLAND ROAD IN THE STATES OF OHIO, INDIANA, AND ILLINOIS, EACH STATE TO BEAR ITS PROPORTION OF THE ABOVE MENTIONED AMOUNT.  (P. 391)

TO AMEND H.R. 501 TO GRANT APPROPRIATIONS FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE OHIO RIVER ABOVE THE FALLS AT LOUISVILLE, PLUS AN ADDITIONAL SUM FOR THE IMPROVEMENT BELOW THE FALLS AND FOR THE IMPROVEMENT OF THE MISSISSIPPI, MISSOURI AND ARKANSAS RIVERS.  (P. 391)
TO AMEND H.R. 501 TO ELIMINATE AN APPROPRIATION FOR AN ARMORY AT FORT MASSAC.  (P. 391)
TO PASS, OVER VETO, THE BILL S. 66 (APP. 3/3/1845, 5 STAT. L. 795), RELATING TO REVENUE CUTTERS AND STEAMERS TOGETHER WITH VETO MESSAGE FROM THE PRESIDENT.  (P. 391)

TO AMEND THE BILL H.R. 541, TO MAKE APPROPRIATIONS FOR IMPROVEMENTS OF CERTAIN RIVERS AND HARBORS, THE AMENDMENT APPROPRIATING A SUM FOR IMPROVEMENTS AT SHEBOYGAN, WIS.; DETROIT, MICH., NORWICH, CONN., KENNEBECH RIVER, ME., PASS CHRISTIAN, ME., AND THE MAIL ROUTE BETWEEN MOBILE AND NEW ORLEANS.  (P. 391)
TO TABLE H.R. 541.  (P. 392)
TO PASS H.R. 541.  (P. 393)
